entry.title: India: Tonnes of ammonium nitrate moved to Hyderabad

media:group.media:title: India: Tonnes of ammonium nitrate moved to Hyderabad
media:group.media:description:
Authorities in the south Indian city of Chennai have moved hundreds of tonnes of explosive chemical ammonium nitrate to Hyderabad. That is after customs officers fast-tracked the process following last week's massive explosion in the Lebanese capital, Beirut. The chemical was stored in Chennai since it was confiscated upon arrival five years ago. Al Jazeera's Elizabeth Puranam reports from New Delhi, India.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #India #Explosives

media:group.media:title: S Korea commemorates wartime 'comfort women'
media:group.media:description:
South Korea's president Moon Jae-in has vowed to highlight the plight of the country's last surviving women who were forced to work in Japanese brothels during World War II. His recorded remarks were part of a ceremony held in the city of Cheonan. It is the third year the memorial has been held to remember the victims, who were known by their captors as “comfort women”. The issue continues to be a thorny one between South Korea and Japan. Al Jazeera's Rob McBride reports from Seoul.

entry.title: Beirut’s hospitals, clinics struggle after last week’s deadly blast

media:group.media:title: Beirut’s hospitals, clinics struggle after last week’s deadly blast
media:group.media:description:
Beirut's hospitals are struggling to cope following the damage from last week's devastating port explosion. Three big hospitals and half of the clinics in the Lebanese capital are still not functioning, leaving the city with an acute shortage of hospital beds. Al Jazeera's Bernard Smith reports.

entry.title: Sierra Leone: Fears of malaria spike during pandemic

media:group.media:title: Sierra Leone: Fears of malaria spike during pandemic
media:group.media:description:
Malaria season has started in Africa and doctors in Sierra Leone are warning that parents avoiding healthcare during the pandemic could lead to more infant deaths. The aid agency Doctors Without Borders, known by its French initials MSF, says children are arriving at hospitals severely malnourished and there are fears of a malaria crisis. Al Jazeera's Sara Khairat reports.

entry.title: Trump says COVID-19 aid stalled over funds for US Postal Service

media:group.media:title: Trump says COVID-19 aid stalled over funds for US Postal Service
media:group.media:description:
President Donald Trump has acknowledged that he is starving the US Postal Service of money. He wants to make it harder to process an expected surge of mail-in ballots. He claims, without offering evidence, that postal voting will result in widespread fraud. Al Jazeera's Patty Culhane reports.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Trump #MailInVoting

entry.title: Mexico signs COVID-19 vaccine deal as cases top 500,000

media:group.media:title: Mexico signs COVID-19 vaccine deal as cases top 500,000
media:group.media:description:
One vaccine in development in the United Kingdom is already being lined up for Latin America. Mexico has reached a deal with Argentina to mass-produce the vaccine for the entire region. Al Jazeera's John Holman reports.

entry.title: More than 9,000 arrests in Ethiopia since June killing of singer

media:group.media:title: More than 9,000 arrests in Ethiopia since June killing of singer
media:group.media:description:
Ethiopian police have arrested more than 9,000 people since a popular musician was killed in June, sparking days of violence. Several opposition leaders are among those who have been arrested as Al Jazeera's Catherine Soi reports.

entry.title: Could fighting in northern Mozambique destabilise the region? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Could fighting in northern Mozambique destabilise the region? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Government forces in Mozambique are fighting to regain control of a remote area in the north. Soldiers are trying to push back ISIL-linked fighters in Cabo Delgado province, a resource-rich region. The fighters have taken control of the port of Mocimboa da Praia near offshore gas projects. Over the past three years, monitoring groups say more than 1,500 people have been killed. Will other countries need to intervene to stem the violence?
Presenter: Imran Khan
Guests:
Tom Bowker - Editor of the Mozambican news website Zitamar.
Zeinado Machado - Researcher in the Africa Division at Human Rights Watch.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Mozambique #InsideStory

entry.title: COVID-19 vaccine: Safety concerns as countries rush for cure

media:group.media:title: COVID-19 vaccine: Safety concerns as countries rush for cure
media:group.media:description:
There are more than 150 coronavirus vaccines in development around the world. But fewer than 10 have reached stage three, the final phase before approval and eventual production and distribution. There are worries the rush for a vaccine means safety is being compromised, as Al Jazeera's Gabriel Elizondo reports from New York, US.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Coronavirus #Vaccine

media:group.media:title: Greece-Turkey tension
media:group.media:description:
Tensions are mounting in the eastern Mediterranean between countries vying for the vast deposits of natural gas that have been discovered there. The potential for military action is rising as neighbours forge new alliances and, in some cases, make old wounds worse in the regional scramble to secure energy rights for this century and beyond. Al Jazeera's Charlie Angela reports.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Turkey #Greece

entry.title: African Americans return home to escape racism

media:group.media:title: African Americans return home to escape racism
media:group.media:description:
Black Americans are being invited to migrate to West African countries. Ghana and Senegal are encouraging them to settle, explore and invest. Al Jazeera's Nicolas Haque met some in Daka,r who say they wanted to leave racism and division behind in the US.

entry.title: Belarus releases protesters before EU discussion on sanctions

media:group.media:title: Belarus releases protesters before EU discussion on sanctions
media:group.media:description:
The Belarusian government has begun releasing people who were arrested during protests this week. It issued a rare public apology in what appeared to be an attempt to stop days of unrest. Nearly 7,000 people were rounded up during demonstrations against Sunday's disputed presidential election. Al Jazeera's Step Vaessen reports.

entry.title: Israel, UAE announce normalisation of relations with US help

media:group.media:title: Israel, UAE announce normalisation of relations with US help
media:group.media:description:
It is an agreement that is being called a betrayal to the Palestinian cause. The UAE's government struck a deal with Israel to normalise relations. US President Donald Trump helped broker it. As part of the agreement, Israel will suspend, but not scrap, plans to annex Palestinian territory. Al Jazeera's Alan Fisher reports from Washington, DC.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Israel #UAE

media:group.media:title: Australia's Cruise Ship Nightmare | 101 East
media:group.media:description:
How did one cruise ship become the single largest source of COVID-19 infections in Australia?
As the pandemic gathered speed and the world went into lockdown in March, the Ruby Princess continued sailing.
Management were well aware of the risks but as the virus silently spread, passengers were reassured there was nothing to fear and the party continued.
When the ship docked weeks later in Sydney, at least 850 people had been infected. They walked straight out into the community.
101 East investigates how the Ruby Princess became an incubator for infection, leaving its passengers and staff dangerously exposed.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Will Kamala Harris help Joe Biden's bid for the White House? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Will Kamala Harris help Joe Biden's bid for the White House? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
U.S. Senator Kamala Harris has joined Joe Biden's presidential campagin. Biden's choice of a black woman of Indian-descent as his Vice President, comes at a crucial time for the United States. President Donald Trump is facing mounting pressure over systemic racism and police brutality. He's also been accused of mismanaging the COVID-19 pandemic. And during their first campagin event together - Biden and Harris went after the president's track record. They said Trump has failed to lead the nation and run the economy into the ground. In a time of increasing racial tension, what role will Kamala Harris play?
Presenter: Hashem Ahelbarra
Guests:
Janelle King, Republican Analyst
Richard Painter, former Chief Ethics Lawyer, for President George W. Bush and is now a Professor at University of Minnesota Law School.
Trevor Hunnicutt, Political Correspondent embedded with the Biden Campaign for the Reuters news agency.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Biden #US #USElection
